results.title: Film editing: interpretation and evaluation
results.brief_description: Contrasts the work of three Hollywood editors. Shows that the manner in which the film is sequenced, determines the dramatic effect. Firstly we see the film exactly as shot for a dramatic sequence, showing all scenes from various angles. Following these are three editing interpretations of the sequence by different editors. Demonstrates how, in assembling the shots, by omitting and shortening others and by different juxtaposition, the editor may control the dramatic construction. Looks at how a scene from the television series “Gunsmoke” is interpreted by different editing.

results.title: Farewell to childhood
results.creator_credit: Julian Roffman, Herbert Kerkow and Mental Health Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows common problems of adolescents and their parents. A moody 15 year-old girl clashes with her parents when they frustrate her efforts to “run her own life”. Mistakes by the parents, such as scolding her in front of her young escort, widen the rift between parents and daughter. Conditions improve when the girl’s teacher arranges a thorough discussion of adolescent problems, bringing more tolerance to both sides.

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: David Plummer, Donald Crombie, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Exploration 1770, reviewed 1970
results.creator_credit: Tim Reid, Frank Bagnall, Stanley Dalby and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Contrasts Captain Cook’s observations on his voyage along the eastern coast of Australia in 1770 with scenes of the Royal Visit in 1970 and bicentenary celebrations including re-enactments of his landings. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Evictions
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Richard Lowenstein
results.brief_description: Documentary/drama on police-enforced evictions in Melbourne during the 1930’s depression and the tactics the organised unemployed used at the time to combat the situation. Based on the memories of Noel Counihan and Tom Hills and adapted from the book ‘Weevils in the flour’ by Wendy Lowenstein, the film combines interviews with period reconstruction. Erwin Rado Award for Best Australian Short Fiction, Melbourne Film Festival, 1980.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Richard Lowenstein

results.title: Everything under the sun [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Don Murray
results.brief_description: Who are the Australians? The film shows them at work, at home and at play. It depicts the sophistication of the cities and the sparseness of the outback. It reveals that already there are traditions and national pride. A study of Australia and Australians with all the variety and colour of the modern Australian scene. Note: A short version, intended mainly for overseas viewers, of “After Cook”. In English and Italian.

results.title: Ever since Giza
results.creator_credit: Ted Davis and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This film tells of the history of barley. A grain of antiquity - seeds were placed in the ancient pyramids of Giza. The experimental work done by Victorian and South Australian agencies to improve the barley crop through the development of more suitable varieties for areas of different climate, standard-isation of seed and better farming techniques is shown. This film was included in the San Francisco Film Festival 1964.

results.title: Encounter
results.creator_credit: Dept of Agriculture, Vic and Victoria. Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs
results.brief_description: Lake Tyers was the site of a ten day multi-cultural camp for boys. Under the watchful eyes of voluntary skilled instructors the boys swam, sailed, canoed, scuba-dived, went hiking, fishing and played the residents at cricket. They made friends and learned teamwork and co-operation. Narrated by David Johnson.

results.title: Don't be strained
results.creator_credit: Stan Murdoch, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1963 film illustrates techniques for manual handling to avoid muscle strain. The film shows workers in various factories undertaking manual labour, and includes footage of an officer of the New South Wales Department of Public Health instructing workers on the correct methods of lifting to avoid injuries such as muscle strain, slipped discs and hernias. The film applies these methods of lifting to other scenarios, including a woman at a filing cabinet, a woman putting out the washing and a postman bending to a letterbox. The narrator refers to ‘the human machine’ throughout the film.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be shocked
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1959 film outlines safe practices in using electical appliances and apparatus in factory environments. It covers the proper care and use of plugs, powerpoints, fuses, flex and extension cords.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
